{{good article}} {{Use American English|date=July 2016}} {{Use mdy dates|date=July 2016}} {{Infobox video game | title = Viva Piñata | image = Viva Piñata cover.jpg | developer = [[Rare (company)|Rare]] | publisher = [[Microsoft Studios|Microsoft Game Studios]] | designer = [[Gregg Mayles]] | composer = [[Grant Kirkhope]] | series = ''[[Viva Piñata]]'' | engine = | released = '''Xbox 360'''{{vgrelease|NA|November 9, 2006|AUS|November 30, 2006}}{{vgrelease|EU|December 1, 2006}}'''Microsoft Windows'''{{vgrelease|NA|November 6, 2007|AUS|November 15, 2007}}{{vgrelease|EU|November 16, 2007}} | genre = [[Life simulation game|Life simulation]] | modes = [[Single-player]] | platforms = [[Xbox 360]], [[Microsoft Windows]] }} '''''Viva Piñata''''' is a 2006 [[life simulation game]] developed by [[Rare (company)|Rare]] and published by [[Microsoft Game Studios]] for the [[Xbox 360]]. The game revolves around the player tending to a neglected garden in Piñata Island, in which different variations of piñatas must be bred whilst fending off disruptive interlopers. The project was headed by [[Gregg Mayles]] and the team behind the [[Banjo-Kazooie series|''Banjo-Kazooie'' series]], based on an idea from Rare co-founder [[Tim and Chris Stamper|Tim Stamper]]. Microsoft wanted the game to become a key franchise for the platform, and developed [[Viva Piñata (TV series)|a tie-in television show]] to accompany the series. ''Viva Piñata'' was released in November 2006. The game received positive reviews from critics, who praised the graphics, color palette, and numerous types of piñatas. They disliked the disruption caused by frequent autosaving. A [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]] version was released in November 2007. The game started the [[Viva Piñata|''Viva Piñata'' series]], with [[Viva Piñata: Trouble in Paradise|a direct sequel]] and [[Viva Piñata: Pocket Paradise|a portable version]] both released in 2008. ''Viva Piñata'' is included in Rare's 2015 ''[[Rare Replay]]'', a compilation of 30 games for the [[Xbox One]]. ==Gameplay== [[File:VP screenshot.jpg|left|250px|thumb|A screenshot of a garden. The top-right corner displays the clock, and the foreground shows various types of piñatas.]] ''Viva Piñata'' is a [[First person (video games)|first-person]] [[life simulation game]] in which the player restores and tends to a neglected garden on Piñata Island.{{cite web|last=Perry|first=Douglas C.|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2006/03/15/viva-pinata-first-look|title=Viva Piñata First Look|work=[[IGN]]|publisher=[[Ziff Davis]]|date=March 15, 2006|accessdate=October 10, 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141124080620/http://uk.ign.com/articles/2006/03/15/viva-pinata-first-look|archivedate=November 24, 2014|deadurl=no}} The player uses gardening tools, such as [[shovels]] and watering cans, to [[plough]] their garden, [[sowing|sow seeds]], create ponds, and sculpt the garden to their liking.{{cite web|last=Orry|first=Tom|url=http://www.videogamer.com/xbox360/viva_pinata/review.html|title=Viva Piñata Review for Xbox 360|work=VideoGamer.com|publisher=Pro-G Media|date=December 4, 2006|accessdate=October 10, 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080904225554/http://www.videogamer.com/xbox360/viva_pinata/review.html|archivedate=September 4, 2008|deadurl=no}}{{cite book | year=2006 |author=Rare| title=Viva Piñata ''instruction manual'' | page=15 | publisher=[[Microsoft Studios]] |ref=harv}} When certain requirements are fulfilled, the garden will attract a black-and-white outline of a given piñata species. After fulfilling additional requirements, the piñata will become a resident, changing into a full-color version. Once two piñatas of the same species are residents and their [[mating]] requirements are met, they can perform a "romance" dance. If the player successfully completes a maze [[minigame]], the romance results in a baby piñata egg, which is delivered by a [[stork]]. The piñatas are not gendered, and hence any two piñatas of the same species can mate.{{sfn|Rare|p=18|2006}} Once a piñata species has successfully romanced, the player can use a candy shortcut to bypass their original romance requirements.{{sfn|Rare|p=19|2006}} The player can hatch the egg or send it to another player over [[Xbox Live]].{{cite web|last1=Cundy|first1=Matt|title=Viva Pinata review|url=http://www.gamesradar.com/viva-pinata-12/2/|website=Games Radar|publisher=Future plc|accessdate=May 13, 2016|date=October 11, 2006}} The game's antagonists include the "Ruffians" led by Professor Pester{{sfn|Rare|p=25|2006}} and "sour piñatas" who occasionally enter the player's garden with the sole intent of wreaking havoc: eating seeds, dropping poisonous piñata candies, and destroying objects.{{sfn|Rare|2006|p=24}} The player may tame sour piñatas by constructing fences around them. Weeds may occasionally sprout in the player's garden and will quickly spread to destroy vegetable rows if the player does not kill them in time.{{sfn|Rare|2006|p=24}} The game features sixty types of piñatas. Certain animals are "piñatavores", and must eat other piñatas to become residents or reproduce.{{cite web|last1=Grazini|first1=Gabe|title=Viva Pinata – hands-on|url=http://www.gamesradar.com/viva-pinata-hands-on/|website=Games Radar|publisher=Future plc|accessdate=May 13, 2016|date=November 1, 2006}} A [[food chain]] (referred to as the ''doughnut of life''){{cite web|url=http://www.gamepro.com/microsoft/xbox360/games/reviews/88170.shtml|title=Review: Viva Piñata|publisher=GamePro|date=December 4, 2006|accessdate=February 23, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061207024616/http://www.gamepro.com/microsoft/xbox360/games/reviews/88170.shtml|archivedate=December 7, 2006}} exists, with a number of piñata species having one or two others that are considered [[predation|prey]]. When such piñatas are visiting the garden, they devour garden residents to satisfy their residency requirements. Once piñatas are residents, they will not eat each other unless instructed to do so by the player, although fights can break out between residents who do not share the predator–prey relationship. Piñatas die when they are broken open, either from another piñata's predaciousness, the hit of the player's or Professor Pester's shovel, or following an extended illness.{{cite web|last1=Gibson|first1=Ellie|title=Viva Pinata review|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/fi_vivapinata_x360|publisher=Eurogamer|accessdate=May 13, 2016|date=October 19, 2006}} Dead piñatas forfeit their equipped accessories. ==Development== [[Rare (company)|Rare]] co-founder Tim Stamper conceptualized a gardening game for the handheld [[Pocket PC]] platform in 2002.{{cite web|url=http://mundorare.com/old/especial/pinatoween/interview.html|title=Interview with the Piñata Team|work=MundoRare|accessdate=February 23, 2007 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070124034234/http://www.mundorare.com/especial/pinatoween/interview.html |archivedate = January 24, 2007}} A three-person team began work on a simple prototype while the company was still affiliated with [[Nintendo]], prior to its [[Microsoft]] acquisition.{{cite web|last=Bramwell|first=Tom|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/article.php?article_id=70473|title=A Rare pleasure Page 1|work=[[Eurogamer]]|publisher=Gamer Network|date=November 29, 2006|accessdate=February 23, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150911031312/http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/eg_rare_int|archivedate=September 11, 2015|deadurl=no}}{{efn|Online connectivity was needed to be able to trade with other players.}} Development transferred to the original [[Xbox (console)|Xbox]] and, ultimately, to the [[Xbox 360]] for its enhanced graphical capabilities. The development team wanted its animals to have a unified style, which was how the concept artist arrived at the [[piñata]] conceit. The idea was exciting for the team, as piñatas were not commonplace in the United Kingdom. The connection between piñatas and candy-filled insides led to new gameplay directions. The ''Viva Piñata'' team was a model for productivity and regular output within Rare and [[Microsoft Studios]]. Though compared to the 12-person teams behind earlier Rare games, the company's Xbox 360 development teams consisted of 50 to 60 people. The ''Viva Piñata'' team included about 50 people at its zenith.{{cite web|url=http://www.mundorare.com/especial/pinatoween/chronicle.html|title= Tasting piñata sweets before Halloween|work=MundoRare|accessdate=February 23, 2007 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070105165151/http://www.mundorare.com/especial/pinatoween/chronicle.html |archivedate = January 5, 2007}} Microsoft transitioned its development teams to use its [[Microsoft XNA|XNA]] package to streamline and reduce duplication in engineering efforts. Microsoft pressured the ''Viva Piñata'' development team to keep the game's themes children-friendly, as the parent company planned for the game and resulting franchise to increase the market appeal of their Xbox 360. In 2006, a Microsoft Games executive called the game its most important franchise. But its reception was tepid. ''Viva Piñata'' was planned as a larger intellectual property. 4Kids TV had agreed to make a ''Viva Piñata'' cartoon before the game was released. 4Kids selected the series out of several Microsoft properties offered. 4Kids also handled the series merchandising. The cartoon is tied very closely to the game, and its animations are based on the game's own 3D character models. Its episodes are approved by Rare's [[Gregg Mayles]] for their applicability to the game. The cartoon was also designed to give viewers tips on how to interact with the in-game piñatas. The animated series' storyline later influenced the plot of ''Trouble in Paradise''. ===Release=== [[Image:Viva World's Largest Pinata.jpg|thumb|right|Horstachio, the world's largest piñata]] After the release of ''Viva Piñata'' in 2006, its development team saw it as incomplete. The developers cut partial ideas from the release to meet their deadlines. Rare's [[Gregg Mayles]] said that the game sold well and steadily on par with their expectations and Xbox executive [[Phil Spencer (business executive)|Phil Spencer]] added that the game was considered a success inside the company. The team incorporated player feedback and worked towards a "more definitive version" of the original. During the Microsoft press conference at [[E3 (Electronic Entertainment Expo)|E3]] 2007, a [[Microsoft Windows]] port of ''Viva Piñata'' was announced. The conversion was handled by [[Climax Group]].{{cite web|title=Microsoft Delivers More Fun, More Experiences and More Choices to Its Ever-Expanding Games Library|url=http://www.gamesindustry.biz/articles/microsoft-delivers-more-fun-more-experiences-and-more-choices-to-its-ever-expanding-games-library|website=Gamesindustry.biz|publisher=Gamer Network|accessdate=May 13, 2016|date=August 24, 2006}}{{cite web|title=Viva Pinata overview|url=http://www.polygon.com/game/viva-pinata/37867|publisher=Polygon|accessdate=May 13, 2016}} The game is part of the [[Games for Windows]] programme which offers easier installation and support for Windows Vista's Games Explorer, [[Xbox 360 Controller]] for Windows, Parental Controls, and the use of [[Games For Windows - Live]].{{cite web|last1=Faylor|first1=Chris|title=Microsoft Launches Games for Windows Live Marketplace with Viva Pinata Demo|url=http://www.shacknews.com/article/56201/microsoft-launches-games-for-windows|publisher=Shacknews|accessdate=May 13, 2016|date=December 2008}} In 2007, Microsoft collaborated with amusement park [[Six Flags Mexico]] to promote the Xbox 360 as well as ''Viva Piñata''. To accomplish this, a {{convert|48|ft}} tall, {{convert|52|ft}} long piñata, specifically a Horstachio, was constructed at the park. At the time, it was the largest recorded piñata ever built.{{cite web|url=http://www.ultimavida.com/2006/12/03/la-pinata-mas-grande-del-mundo-2|title= La piñata más grande del mundo|work=Última Vida|accessdate=February 23, 2007}} ==Reception== {{Video game reviews | MC = X360: 84/100{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/xbox-360/viva-pinata|title=Viva Pinata – X360|publisher=[[Metacritic]]|accessdate=March 17, 2012}}
PC: 78/100{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/viva-pinata|title=Viva Pinata – PC|publisher=[[Metacritic]]|accessdate=March 17, 2012}} | 1UP = X360: A{{cite web|url=http://www.1up.com/do/reviewPage?cId=3155297|title=Viva Pinata Review from 1UP.com|last=Davison|first=John|publisher=[[1UP.com]]|date=November 15, 2006|access-date=March 15, 2007|archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/6642dz4fL?url=http://www.1up.com/reviews/viva-pinata|archive-date=March 10, 2012|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} | GSpot = X360: 8.3/10{{cite web|last=Calvert|first=Justin|url=http://www.gamespot.com/reviews/viva-pinata-review/1900-6161804/|title=Viva Pinata Review Xbox 360 – GameSpot|work=[[GameSpot]]|publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]|date=November 16, 2006|accessdate=March 17, 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141117170829/http://www.gamespot.com/reviews/viva-pinata-review/1900-6161804/|archivedate=November 17, 2014|deadurl=no}}
PC: 7.5/10{{cite web|url=http://uk.gamespot.com/viva-pinata/reviews/viva-piata-review-6182974/|title=Viva Pinata Review – PC|publisher=[[GameSpot]]|first=Justin|last=Calvert|date=November 15, 2007|accessdate=March 17, 2012}} | GSpy = X360: 9/10{{cite web|last1=Villoria|first1=Gerald|title=Viva Pinata review|url=http://xbox360.gamespy.com/xbox-360/viva-pi241ata/745688p1.html|website=GameSpy|publisher=IGN|accessdate=May 12, 2016|date=November 13, 2006}} | IGN = X360: 8.5/10{{cite web|url=http://xbox360.ign.com/articles/745/745371p1.html|title=Viva Piñata X360 Review|last= Brudvig|first=Erik|publisher=[[IGN]]|date=November 10, 2006|accessdate=March 17, 2012}}
PC: 8.2/10{{cite web|url=http://pc.ign.com/articles/834/834989p1.html|title=Viva Piñata PC Review|last= Adams|first=Dan|publisher=[[IGN]]|date=November 14, 2007|accessdate=March 17, 2012}} | OXMUK = X360: 8/10{{cite web|url=http://www.oxm.co.uk/111/reviews/viva-piata-review/|title=Viva Pinata Review|publisher=[[Official Xbox Magazine]]|first=Andrew|last=Taylor|accessdate=March 17, 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130131033805/http://www.oxm.co.uk/111/reviews/viva-piata-review|archivedate=January 31, 2013}} | TX = X360: 8.4/10{{cite web|url=http://reviews.teamxbox.com/xbox-360/1251/Viva-Piata/p1/|title=Viva Piñata Review (Xbox 360)| last=Tuttle|first=Will|publisher=[[TeamXbox]]|date=November 10, 2006|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090929020524/http://reviews.teamxbox.com/xbox-360/1251/Viva-Piata/p2/|archivedate=September 29, 2009}} }} ''Viva Piñata'' received "generally favorable" reviews, according to video game [[review aggregator]] [[Metacritic]]. Nearly a year after its release, Rare's Justin Cook said that the game had sold about 500,000 copies.{{Cite web |last1=Sheffield |first1=Brandon |title=A Rare Opportunity: On Piñatas, Microsoft and More |work=[[Gamasutra]] |date=2007-10-12 |url=http://www.gamasutra.com/view/feature/1953/a_rare_opportunity_on_piatas_.php?print=1 |accessdate=2016-07-05 |df=mdy-all |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111109081236/http://www.gamasutra.com/view/feature/1953/a_rare_opportunity_on_piatas_.php?print=1 |archivedate=November 9, 2011 |deadurl=no}} The graphics were unanimously praised by critics. Justin Calvert of [[GameSpot]] stated the attention to detail was "uniformly impressive", and asserted that the visuals were cohesive. Erik Brudvig of [[IGN]] found that the game's graphical slowdown during its frequent autosaving to be startling, although he praised the presentation overall. Andrew Taylor of the ''[[Official Xbox Magazine]]'' praised the vibrant use of colors and attention to detail. Will Tuttle of [[Team Xbox]] similarly stated the colors were "vividly vibrant" and the design aesthetics "remarkably appealing", although he also found the autosaving slowdown frustrating. Gerald Villoria of [[GameSpy]] stated the graphics were "breathtaking", and noted the color palettes of the piñatas themselves gave the appearance that they were "stripped directly from an animated show". Critics commended various aspects of the gameplay. Calvert enjoyed the wide customization options and large number of piñata variations, stating that the gameplay itself was "silky smooth". Brudvig noted that there was a "ton to do"; he praised the encouragement of discovery and stated that it was "constantly filled with moments where you find something new to do". Tuttle commended the large number of piñatas, stating that finding managing all of the resources is "a lot of work". Villoria praised the "surprisingly deep" strategic gameplay, saying that it was one of the most "entertaining and fulfilling" experiences for the Xbox 360. ''Viva Piñata'' was nominated for six awards by the [[Academy of Interactive Arts and Sciences]] for its 10th annual awards covering 2006.{{cite web|url=http://www.interactive.org/awards.php?winners&year=2007|title=AIAS 10th annual awards|publisher=[[Academy of Interactive Arts & Sciences]]|accessdate=February 9, 2007 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070208212402/http://interactive.org/awards.php?winners&year=2007 |archivedate = February 8, 2007}} The music score by [[Grant Kirkhope]] was nominated for Original Score at the 2007 BAFTA awards. The game was nominated for the "Best Original Game" in [[X-Play]]'s "Best Video Games of 2006" awards.{{cite web|url= http://www.g4tv.com/g4/press/162/G4s_XPLAY_Unveils_Nominations_for_Best_Video_Games_of_2006.html|title=G4's 'X-PLAY' Unveils Nominations for Best Video Games of 2006|publisher=[[G4 (U.S. TV channel)|G4TV]]|date=December 8, 2006|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120331031252/http://www.g4tv.com/g4/press/162/G4s_XPLAY_Unveils_Nominations_for_Best_Video_Games_of_2006.html |archivedate=March 31, 2012 |deadurl=yes}} Other accolades include a [[Parents' Choice Award]] from the Parents' Choice Foundation.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamasutra.com/php-bin/news_index.php?story=13736| title=Gamasutra – Viva Pinata Takes Top Parents' Choice Award|publisher=[[Gamasutra]]|date=April 30, 2007}} and GameSpot included the title as one of their ten nominees for their "2006 Game of the Year" award, although it received only 3% of the total votes.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/special_features/bestof2006/gameofyear/index.html?page=2|title=Best Games and Worst Games of 2006 at GameSpot|publisher=[[GameSpot]]|accessdate=February 23, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130308123934/http://www.gamespot.com/special_features/bestof2006/gameofyear/index.html?page=2 |archivedate=March 8, 2013 |deadurl=no}} ===Legacy=== A sequel, ''[[Viva Piñata: Trouble in Paradise]]'' was announced in May 2008 and released in September of that year.{{cite web|title=Hands-On: Viva Pinata Trouble in Paradise|url=https://www.wired.com/2008/05/hands-on-viva-p/|publisher=Wired|accessdate=May 13, 2016|date=May 13, 2008}}{{cite web|last1=Alexander|first1=Leigh|title=Viva Piñata: Trouble in Paradise Date And Details|url=http://kotaku.com/5022025/viva-piata-trouble-in-paradise-date-and-details|publisher=Kotaku|accessdate=May 13, 2016|date=July 3, 2008}} The sequel adds more than 30 new piñata species, a "Just for Fun" sandbox mode, and new co-operative modes, as well as new desert and arctic environments.{{cite web|last1=McShea|first1=Tom|title=Viva Pinata: Trouble in Paradise review|url=http://www.gamespot.com/reviews/viva-pinata-trouble-in-paradise-review/1900-6197035/|publisher=GameSpot|accessdate=May 13, 2016|date=September 2, 2008}} Rare announced plans to release a Nintendo DS version of the game at [[Comic-Con International|Comic-Con]] 2007.{{cite web|last1=Arendt|first1=Susan|title=Viva Pinata Coming to DS|url=https://www.wired.com/2007/07/viva-pinata-com/|publisher=Wired|accessdate=May 13, 2016|date=July 11, 2007}} It was later revealed to be titled ''[[Viva Piñata: Pocket Paradise]]'' and was subsequently released in September 2008. Key changes include a control scheme which makes use of the stylus, as well as the presence of additional context-sensitive information on the second screen.{{cite web|last1=Bozon|first1=Mark|title=Viva Pinata: Pocket Paradise review|url=http://uk.ign.com/articles/2008/09/02/viva-piaata-pocket-paradise-review|website=IGN|publisher=Ziff Davis|accessdate=May 13, 2016|date=September 2, 2008}} On October 30, 2007, a [[party game]] spin-off, ''[[Viva Piñata: Party Animals]]'' was released for the Xbox 360.{{cite web|last1=Ahearn|first1=Nate|title=Viva Pinata: Party Animals review|url=http://uk.ign.com/articles/2007/10/31/viva-piaata-party-animals-review|website=IGN|publisher=Ziff Davis|accessdate=May 13, 2016|date=October 30, 2007}} Developed by [[Krome Studios]], the game features the TV show piñata characters competing in races and close to 50 party [[mini-games]].{{cite web|last1=Davis|first1=Ryan|title=Viva Pinata: Party Animals review|url=http://www.gamespot.com/reviews/viva-piyata-party-animals-review/1900-6182112/|publisher=GameSpot|accessdate=May 13, 2016|date=October 31, 2007}} ==Notes== {{notelist}} ==References== {{Infobox animal | name = Warren Remedy | image = Warren_remedy.jpg | image_size = | caption = Ch. Warren Remedy | birth_name = | othername = | species = [[Dog]] | breed = [[Fox Terrier (Smooth)|Smooth-coated Fox Terrier]]{{cite news | url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1907/02/15/106706137.pdf | title=Fox Terrier Wins Blue Ribbon Event | newspaper=New York Times | date=February 15, 1907 | accessdate=January 30, 2013|format=PDF}} | gender = Female{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/?id=bApdkUfLD-4C&pg=PA123&dq=%22Warren+Remedy%22#v=onepage&q=%22Warren%20Remedy%22&f=false | title=The Dog Show: 125 Years of Westminster | publisher=Globe Pequot | date=November 1, 2003 | accessdate=January 30, 2013 | author=Stifel, William F.| isbn=9781592282630 }} | birth_date = 1905 | birth_place = [[Allamuchy Township, New Jersey]] | death_date = December 1912 | death_place = Allamuchy Township, New Jersey | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | nationality = American | occupation = Show dog | years_active = | known = | title = Best in Show winner, [[Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show]] | term = 1907-1909 | successor = [[Sabine Rarebit]] | owner = Winthrop Rutherford | parents = Sabine Resist (sire)
Routon Dainty (dam) | children = | weight = {{convert|20|lb|kg}} | height = | appearance = }} '''[[Champion (dog)|Ch.]] Warren Remedy''', (1905-1912), was a Best in Show winner of the [[Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show]] in 1907, 1908, and 1909. She was a [[Fox Terrier (Smooth)|Smooth-coated fox terrier]] owned by [[Winthrop Rutherfurd]], and is the only dog to have won Westminster three years in a row.{{cite book|last=Bengtson|first=Bo|title=Best in show|year=2008|publisher=Kennel Club books|location=Freehold, NJ 07728, USA|isbn=978 1 931993 85 2|page=289}} ==Early life== Remedy was sired by Sabine Resist from Routon Dainty. She was bred by [[Winthrop Rutherfurd]], and brought up at the Warren Kennels in [[Allamuchy Township, New Jersey]].{{cite news|title=American Dogs Ahead|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1907/03/03/104981351.pdf|accessdate=February 6, 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=March 3, 1907|format=PDF}} Other dogs which were bred from the same pairing included Warren Drastic, Warren Deputy, Warren Vogue and Warren Rescue.{{cite news|title=Fox Terrier Warren Remedy Dead|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1912/12/17/100385000.pdf|accessdate=February 6, 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=December 12, 1912}} ==Show career== The [[Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show]] introduced a Best in Show competition in 1907, the first since the show's inception in 1877.{{cite web|title=Club History|url=http://www.westminsterkennelclub.org/about/history.html|publisher=Westminster Kennel Club|accessdate=February 6, 2013}} At the age of 20 months, Warren Remedy was entered in the competition and progressed through breed and group victories into the Best in Show round. She faced off against sixteen other breeds of dogs. These included the [[Rough Collie]] Squire of Tytton, who had won the Van Schaick Cup earlier in the show, and the [[Old English Sheepdog|English Sheepdog]] Dolly Gray, who won the Castle Gould Cup. Ten judges preceded over the Best in Show round and awarded the title to Warren Remedy. Immediately afterwards, Remedy competed once again at the show, this time for Ballyhoo Bay Challenge Cup awarded by the Ladies Kennel Association of America. A similar lineup of dogs competed for the trophy, with the exception of Squire of Tytton being replaced with the American-bred Rough Collie Mountaineer Magistrate. Remedy was expected to win this title as well, but it was instead awarded to the [[English Setter]] Deodora Prince. Later in the 1907 show season, Remedy was named Best in Show at the inaugural North Jersey Kennel Club dog show.{{cite news|title=Warren Remedy Best Dog|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1907/08/16/106712914.pdf|accessdate=February 6, 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=August 16, 1907|format=PDF}} A week after that victory and also in New Jersey, Remedy also won the award for the best dog or bitch in show at the [[Asbury Park, New Jersey|Asbury Park]] dog show.{{cite news|title=Warren Remedy Best Dog|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1907/08/22/106713139.pdf|accessdate=February 6, 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=August 22, 1907|format=PDF}} Remedy retained the Best in Show title at the Westminster Kennel Club show in 1908, and afterwards was declared to be the "best dog of her kind in America".{{cite news|title=Prize Dogs Draw Record Patronage|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1908/02/13/105002882.pdf|accessdate=February 6, 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=February 13, 1908|format=PDF}} Later in 1908, Remedy was named the best bitch in the show at the Ladies Kennel Association of America show held in [[Mineola, New York]].{{cite news|title=More Surprises in Dog Show Awards|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1908/06/06/104729346.pdf|accessdate=February 6, 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=June 6, 1908|format=PDF}} She won Westminster once again in 1909, although reports mistakenly gave her name as "Warren Rutherford".{{cite news|title=Bulldog Gamin II Sold for Big Price|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1909/02/13/106117077.pdf|accessdate=February 6, 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=February 13, 1909|format=PDF}} Following her victory at Westminster in 1909, Remedy competed in the New England Kennel Club Show later in the same month. There she was beaten by the Smooth Fox Terrier Sabine Fernie from the Sabine Kennels.{{cite news|title=Sabine Fernie Wins Two Prizes|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1909/02/26/101867841.pdf|accessdate=February 6, 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=February 26, 1909|format=PDF}} At the 1910 Westminster Show, Remedy was beaten in what was viewed as a surprise victory in the best Smooth Fox Terrier bitch contest by Sabine Fernie. Fernie went on to be beaten by fellow Sabine Kennel's dog, Sabine Rarebit in the best overall Smooth Fox Terrier contest.{{cite news|title=Mike, Fireman's Dog, Gets Prize at Show|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1910/02/11/102035857.pdf|accessdate=February 6, 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=February 11, 1910}} Rarebit went on to win the Best in Show title, the first time it had been awarded to a dog other than Warren Remedy.{{cite news|title=Sabine Rarebit is Best Dog in Show|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1910/02/12/104920803.pdf|accessdate=February 6, 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=February 12, 1910|format=PDF}} Warren Remedy's death was reported by ''[[The New York Times]]'' on December 17, 1912. She died in the Warren Kennels on [[Winthrop Rutherfurd|Winthrop Rutherfurd's]] farm in [[Allamuchy Township]]. ==Legacy== Warren Remedy remains the only dog to have won Best in Show at the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show on three occasions, the most victories by any single dog.{{cite news|last=Rosenblum|first=Ira|title=Signoff; Champions All, But Only One Top Dog|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/15/tv/signoff-champions-all-but-only-one-top-dog.html|accessdate=February 6, 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=February 15, 1998}} Bronze statues were later crafted of Remedy's form by Ric Chashoudian. These statues were used as awards to show dog owners for a series of awards by the Westminster Kennel Club. Likewise, crystal statues were created of Warren Remedy were created for the handlers of the show dogs.{{cite news|last=Fletcher|first=Walter R.|title=Westminster Dog Show; Westminster Blends Tradition and Quality|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/08/sports/westminster-dog-show-westminster-blends-tradition-and-quality.html|accessdate=February 6, 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=February 8, 1987}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{Westminster Best in Show 07-70 |state=collapsed}} [[Category:Best in Show winners of the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show]] [[Category:1905 animal births]] [[Category:1912 animal deaths]]

{{Infobox mass murderer | name = Éric Borel | image = Eric Borel.jpg | image_size = | caption = | birthname = Eric Borel | occupation = [[Student]] ([[electromechanics]]) | birth_date = {{Birth date|1978|12|11|df=y}} | birth_place= [[Pau, Pyrénées-Atlantiques|Pau]], [[France]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1995|9|24|1978|12|11|df=y}} | death_place= [[Cuers]], France | cause = [[Suicide]] by [[gunshot injury|gunshot wound]] to the head | penalty = | date = 23–24 September 1995 | targets = | locations = [[Solliès-Pont]] and [[Cuers]], France | fatalities = 16 (including himself) | injuries = 4 | weapons = *[[J. G. Anschütz|Anschütz]] [[.22 LR|.22-caliber]] [[Rifle|hunting rifle]] *[[Hammer]] *[[Baseball bat]] }}
'''Éric Borel''' ({{IPA-fr|bɔʁɛl|lang}}; 11 December 1978 – 24 September 1995) was a [[French people|French]] high-school student and [[spree killer]] who, at the age of 16, murdered his family in [[Solliès-Pont]] in the [[arrondissement of Toulon]] on 23 September 1995, and afterwards shot dead twelve other people and injured four more in the village of [[Cuers]] the next day. When police arrived at the scene, Borel committed [[suicide]].<ref>[http://www.varmatin.com/article/var/dossier-la-tuerie-de-cuers-14-ans-apres-mystere-sur-une-folie-meurtriere.17086.html Dossier : La tuerie de Cuers 14 ans après Mystère sur une folie meurtrière] "Éric Borel, le meurtrier de 16 ans, a emporté dans sa tombe son lourd secret."</ref><ref>[http://www.au-troisieme-oeil.com/index.php?page=actu&type=skr&news=31132 Il y a 14 ans à Cuers, la folie meurtrière d'un jeune homme de 16 ans faisait 17 morts ] "La folie meurtrière d’Éric Borel, un adolescent de 16 ans, est sans précédent en France"</ref>
== Biography ==
=== Childhood === Éric Borel was the son of Marie-Jeanne Parenti and Jacques Borel, who were both working in the military at the time of his birth. However, their liaison was rather short, and after they separated, Eric was sent to Jacques Borel's parents in [[Limoges]], where he stayed until he was five. When his mother, who had visited Eric only occasionally up to that time, began to live with Yves Bichet, she again took care of her son, much to his dislike, and took him to their home in [[Solliès-Pont]].<ref name=dossier>[http://www.affaires-criminelles.com/dossier_19-1.php La tuerie de Cuers] (in [[French (language)|French]]), ''affaires-criminelles.com''</ref><ref name=spiegel>[http://www.spiegel.de/spiegel/print/d-9225846.html?name=Eine+Art+von+Rache Eine Art von Rache] (in [[German (language)|German]]), ''[[Der Spiegel]]'' (41/1995)</ref>
Borel's mother, an [[authoritarian]] and – at least outwardly – religious person and activist in the [[Catholic Relief Services|Secours catholique]],<ref>[https://www.humanite.fr/1995-09-26_Articles_-Plonges-dans-le-traumatisme-deux-villages-veulent-comprendre Plongés dans le traumatisme deux villages veulent comprendre], ''[[L'Humanité]]'' (September 26, 1995)</ref> mistreated and beat him—she believed him to be a "child of sin". He never developed a close relationship with his mother's new companion, with whom he was said to have frequent rows and who reportedly also beat him on occasions.<ref name=Ind29>[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/a-black-day-in-provence-1603338.html A black day in Provence], ''[[The Independent]]'' (September 29, 1995)</ref> However, Franck and Jean-Luc Bichet, Yves Bichet's sons, stated that their father had always been nice to Eric, even building him a shack for his chickens and other animals he took home.<ref name=spiegel/>
When Eric broke his arm at the age of eight, rather than to go home, he preferred to run away and hide, until he was found, shivering from pain. In this type of situation, Borel, who was known as a quiet and taciturn boy who kept to himself and rather tend the chickens in the backyard during his free time than to go out, grew up and developed an increasing admiration for the military, telling lies about heroic deeds of his father during the [[Indochina Wars|Indochina War]] and adoring his stepbrother Franck Bichet, who served in the army. He had an affection for weapons and used to shoot [[sparrow]]s with an [[air gun]].<ref name=spiegel/>
=== Later years and motive === Until his death, Borel attended the [[Lycée#Lyc.C3.A9e professionnel|lycée professionnel]] Georges-Cisson in [[Toulon]], where he studied electromechanics and did quite well academically. He was said to be a disciplined and quiet student. However, in his last year at school there was a radical change in behavior. He skipped classes without permission or explanation and became unaffable. He regularly said that he could not bear it anymore at home, that he had had enough of doing housework and being called names, and often stated his wish to join the military, like his father and grandfather. Apparently, the week prior to the shooting, he also told one of his classmates that he would commit suicide, but not before killing two or three people.<ref name=dossier/><ref name=Ind29/>
Borel had one friend, 17-year-old Alan Guillemette, a classmate who was rather outgoing and popular among his peers and with whom he would hang out after school.<ref name=Ind29/>
Many reports erroneously stated that Borel's room was full of [[Nazi]]-insignia, and rumors he was sympathizing with fascist ideologies were spurred even more by the fact that his stepfather had attended several meetings of the [[National Front (France)|Front National]] in 1989. But besides a picture of [[Adolf Hitler]] cut out from a newspaper, graffiti displaying a [[swastika]] on his door, a few books on [[World War II]], as well as a documentary about [[David Koresh]] and the [[Waco siege]], no evidence was found after his death that he was interested in any kind of politics.<ref name=Ind29/> Also, a girl from Cuers spread the story that Eric had told her about his relationship with his half-sister Caroline, who was supposed to be his pregnant girlfriend. However, the sister in question did not exist, nor was it true that his father had died of cancer shortly before his rampage.<ref name=spiegel/>
== Attacks ==
=== Familicide === The series of attacks started on 23 September 1995, at about 6:00 p.m. [[Coordinated Universal Time|CET]], when Borel killed his stepfather, Yves Bichet, in the kitchen by shooting him four times with a [[J. G. Anschütz|Anschütz]] [[.22 Long Rifle|.22-caliber]] [[rifle]], before smashing his head with a [[hammer]]. Police assumed that they had a quarrel beforehand, when Borel tried to run away from home. Next, Borel assaulted his half-brother, 11-year-old Jean-Yves Bichet, who was watching TV, in a similar manner, by first shooting him with the rifle and afterwards bludgeoning his head with the hammer. After wiping up the blood trails, Borel waited for his mother to come home.<ref name=dossier/><ref name=Ind29/>
As soon as his mother, Marie-Jeanne Parenti, arrived at home from church at about 8:30 p.m., Borel immediately killed her with a single shot to the head. In contrast to her husband and son no blunt force was used on Mrs. Parenti,<ref name=Ind29/> although some reports have suggested that he beat her as well with either the [[hammer]] or a [[baseball bat]].<ref name=NYT>[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=990CEFD6143AF936A1575AC0A963958260 Teen-Age Gunman Kills Himself and 12 Others in France], ''[[The New York Times]]'' (September 25, 1995)</ref> When his mother lay dead, Borel once again started to clean the house from blood, covered the bodies with sheets and closed all shutters, as well as the steel gate. Carrying a bag packed with food, money, a raincoat, a map of Limoges, and a pistol shooting rubber bullets, which was erroneously identified as a .22-caliber pistol in some reports,<ref>Death brings rampage toll to 13, ''[[Milwaukee Journal Sentinel]]'' (September 26, 1995)</ref><ref>[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/death-toll-in-gun-massacre-rises-to-13-1602941.html Death toll in gun massacre rises to 13], ''[[The Independent]]'' (September 26, 1995)</ref> and armed with his father's rifle and his pockets full of ammunition, Borel made his way towards Cuers, at first by car, but eventually he crashed it into a wall, where he continued his path by foot. Presumably he spent the night between [[Vitis vinifera|vines]].<ref name=spiegel/><ref name=Ind29/>
The bodies of the murdered family were found at approximately 1 a.m. by Yves Bichet's son Jean-Luc, a student living in [[Antibes]] who only occasionally visited his father on weekends. After calling police Bichet was first considered a suspect in the murders when giving contradictory information. The absence of Eric Borel remained undetected until about three hours later.<ref name=spiegel/><ref name=Ocala>[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=pDUVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=0AcEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6899,5582669&dq= Murdering rampage shocks small town], ''[[Ocala Star-Banner]]'' (September 26, 1995)</ref>
=== Shooting spree === On the following day at 7:15 a.m., Borel arrived at the home of his friend Alan Guillemette. When Guillemette's mother opened the door Eric asked her to wake him. The two had a lengthy discussion in the garden, and apparently Eric wanted something from Guillemette, but when he declined and turned to go back into the house, Eric shot him in the back, mortally wounding him.<ref name=dossier/> From 7:30 a.m. onwards, Borel started shooting people at random. No one grew suspicious of his rifle until he started his rampage, since it was [[hunting season]] and the sight of rifles outside was to be expected.
First he shot at Ginette Vialette through an open window, mortally wounding her, as well as Denise Otto, whom he killed, while she was bringing the trash out. He also hit Otto's husband, Jean, in the shoulder. Subsequently Borel injured an elderly woman who was walking in the streets with her husband and shot and wounded two brothers who were crossing his path. The shots he fired at Rodolphe Incorvala, once again through an open window, were eventually lethal. He later died in a hospital. Borel crossed the street to shoot and kill shopkeeper Mario Pagani, who was out buying a newspaper, with shots in the abdomen and head, as well as Mohammed Maarad in front of the "Café du Commerce". Marius Boudon and André Touret were killed while they were drawing money from an [[Automated teller machine|ATM]] and Andrée Coletta while she was taking her poodle for a walk. Finally he shot Pascal Mostacchi to death at Place Peyssoneau.<ref name=dossier/><ref name=spiegel/><ref>[http://www.elmundo.es/papel/hemeroteca/1995/09/25/sociedad/66470.html Un joven neonazi mata a 12 personas en Francia], ''[[El Mundo (Spain)|El Mundo]]'' (September 25, 1995)</ref>
By 8:00 a.m., police arrived at the scene. Realizing that he was surrounded, Borel fatally shot himself in the head under a cypress tree in front of a school.<ref name=Ind29/> Observers of the rampage stated he had been poised and calm all the while, taking great care at aiming and shooting, hitting most of his victims in the head and returning when he did not hit properly the first time. In total, Borel had fired about 40 shots.<ref name=spiegel/><ref name=NYT/>
On 23 October 1995, Jeanne Laugiero, 68, died in hospital from injuries sustained in the shooting, raising the death toll to 14 victims.<ref>''[[Le Monde]]'' (26 October 1995)</ref> The last death in the killing spree was 68-year-old Pierre Marigliano, who succumbed to his wounds on 2 March 1996, bringing the death toll to 15.<ref>''Le Monde'' (March 6, 1996)</ref> Borel's shooting spree was the deadliest act of mass murder in France since [[Christian Dornier]] killed 14 people in [[Luxiol]] on 12 July 1989.<ref name=NYT/>
